author: elizashapiro

text: Right, that’s why I said almost no politicians. And remember, for a reporter whose job it is to hold politicians to account, talking about the issue isn’t the same as taking a position. Trying to bring folks like you actual news. Talk soon.
author: elizashapiro

text: My Twitter is not a comprehensive news digest. I wasn’t at that press conference because I was talking to black and Hispanic children who attend Stuyvesant to hear about their experiences. Encourage you to check out that story as well. Have a good weekend!
author: elizashapiro

text: Definitely encourage you to check out Liu’s quote this week which was on the front page of the Times. Gillibrand commenting on this is newsworthy, whether or not it fits your narrative. She is one of the most powerful pols in the state.
author: elizashapiro

text: Huh? I’m retweeting what one of NY’s senators and a presidential contender for 2020 thinks about what one of the biggest issues in the state. Liu has been in all my articles about this issue and we talk all the time. Read those stories please!

text: Something to think about: most the black and Hispanic students found out that Stuyvesant *existed* just months before they took the exam to get in. Some white and Asian-Americans students know about this test - and prepare for it - years in advance.

text: I've sat through enough hearings to know this may not amount to much, but very notable that the Assembly is reversing course and taking on the specialized high school issue

text: This is new from a legislative body with power over the fate of the specialized high school exam. As of last week, the Assembly hadn't even brought up the issue in debate.

text: I see this trope repeated over and over again in the debate about specialized high schools - even from mainstream politicians and advocacy groups - and in the comment sections of nearly all my stories about NYC public schools.
author: elizashapiro

text: Hi Ray - it was not a rhetorical question. I have been talking to politicians in Albany and NYC for years about this issue and many have not yet taken a position on BdB's proposal. It's my job as a reporter to ask what they think - that way I can tell you what's going on.
author: elizashapiro

text: A question that most politicians in New York would rather not answer, if years of reporting on this issue is any indication

text:
NEWS: Today, seven black students got into Stuyvesant High School, one of the most prestigious public schools in the nation, out of 895 offers. 

The grim statistics will raise pressure on NY's politicians to confront segregation in elite schools.
author: elizashapiro

text: The lock-in is over, but the fight at Fieldston is continuing: a student is suing the school and its principal, Jessica Bagby, alleging racial discrimination. Interestingly, that student did not help organize the lock-in or even participate in it.
